reviewText:
Wow. What a treasure this game is!

From a technical perspective, I admit it's nothing impressive. The background art and character sprites are fairly simple, the music is repetitive and almost a bit plain, and the story is short and straightforward. You won't find yourself wishing you had pillow cases of this game, or wanting to pay for the soundtrack.

But that has never been what makes a game great or memorable.

No matter who you are or what your childhood was like, this game will make you feel something. It will make you remember and reminisce. The entire story is about the protagonist's struggle with having a crush, after his confession to his first love didn't go so well. And this is something that every single one of us can relate to. No matter how your first love turned out, everyone knows that feeling of how the smallest thing can take over your entire horizon until you see nothing, feel nothing, can think of nothing but the person of your affection.

And you will come to love the characters, because you've been in their shoes; you may even have been just like one of them, once upon a time. In fact, I'm certain that you were, even if you don't realize it at first. I know I was. I am a woman in her early 20's at the time of writing this review, and I've rarely self-identified so strongly with a 17/18 year old male protagonist. I adored watching the transformations and metamorphoses of all the characters. Truth be told, the steps they took as individuals were all so small--but that doesn't mean they're insignificant. Sometimes the smallest steps are the most difficult to take, because they're the most easily obscured and forgotten.

And sometimes you may feel that the characters are too self-absorbed, too caught up in themselves, and are overdramaticizing their issues in a passive-aggressive manner. But then you realize that you still do the exact same thing, even today. And for some grandoise, unknown reason, your heart will smile.

This is such a simple game. And in its simplicity it is breathtakingly beautiful. It didn't make me cry; it did much, much more.

reviewText:
I'll be brief: I've played many a doujin novel, and Sepia Tears, while not perfect, is definitely one of the best I've read in recent memory.  I feel the writer was inspired by the works of Key, as there are not only many blatant references to them, but the story as a whole felt similar to Kanon. And that's not a bad thing. (Come on, Key! Release Kanon on Steam already!) :)

The characters are entertaining, although I felt some of the drama was a bit forced. The supporting characters like to pull the main character's leg a lot, and after a while of this it tends to diminish the impact of the honest drama. I honestly wish the choices in the game weren't purely cosmetic, since these characters are so likeable that they deserve their own endings.

But the ending we get is good enough. It takes a bit of persistence, but it's fairly rewarding. You unlock a diary entry after beating the game that fully explains the motivations behind Myra's actions, but I wish there was a little more than that. Maybe I was expecting too much, since May Sky's after story felt a lot meatier... :/

I have a few technical problems, particularly with the script. While I do like the transition to NVL to show when Mark is in deep thought, there are also times when Myra is talking instead, and the novel makes no mention of who's speaking. You may figure it out yourself if you're reading carefully, but it is a little jarring when you don't know who's talking. Aside from the rare typo, the script is pretty clean in terms of grammar and punctuation. The backlog feature is probably the best I've seen in a doujin VN, although it is a little too sensitive when I scroll up.

The graphics are a bit of a mixed bag. The character sprites look like stencil drawings, and the backgrounds look like stock photos altered to look like watercolor paintings. It's a unique style I haven't seen in a doujin VN, and for the most part, it's inoffensive. The CGs, particularly the chibi artwork, are fantastic. The normal CGs are at least consistent with the style of the character sprites, which I can't fault the artist for.

The music is mostly ambient and inoffensive, although very few of the tracks will stick in your head. The ending theme is the standout track in the novel, as the song fits the mood well and is sung pretty well, too. At first I couldn't tell if it was being sung in Japanese or English, because the lyrics were a bit unintelligible. Once I got a handle on the English lyrics, it turned out to be a pretty nice song.

For the price of nothing, Sepia Tears could have turned out a lot worse. But for what I got, it's pretty good. This is probably one of the best doujin novels you could play on Steam. There used to be three free doujin novels that I think are exceptional and totally worth playing (those titles being Brass Restoration, Moonshine, and May Sky), and with this game, a new member has been added to the family. I was disappointed when I reached a certain point in this visual novel.
But why? I was just disappointed that there are not more branches or actual paths in this modest-length visual novel. And that would be because it is surprisingly well written, especially for a free story.
Although digestion of the story can be difficult at first, the underlying themes are beautiful and emotionally touching.

Oh gosh I can't believe I'm doing this, but here we go.

Sepia Tears is a free romance visual novel developed by Scarlet String Studio where you plays as Mark, an average high school student who meets an mysterious girl named Myra who knows about him. Like most visual novels, Sepia Tears presents to you with choices, which will affect the characters and the direction of the story as it progresses.

Now to be honest, I have never played a visual novel for a long while now. In fact this game is my second time playing one since 2012, my first one is a visual novel called Katawa Shoujo and let's just say I'm a fan of that game (Hanako FTW). Anyway, I haven't played one ever since due to my distrust of anime since as much as I love the art style of it. Most of the time, anime styled media often contains very mature content from my experience, so it has made me quite sceptical whenever I see something that's anime though there are exceptions (Katawa Shoujo is one example).

After some time thinking if I should play the game or not, I've decided to download it and play it.

And I do not regret it.

The art style looks great, the characters are well written and believable and the music sounds amazing. The background pictures are all right though they're not too interesting compare to Katawa Shoujo but they are all right. But the big thing I want to talk about is the story and my goodness it's so good and adorable. The story at first may seem confusing but it all nicely wraps up towards the end of the game with a very surprising twist. You are given a good amount of choices but most of them don't really have an effect on the game's story expect for the one near the end of the game.

Most of the choices are kind of there to add an illusion of choice which might not be something that everyone would enjoy, but I don't mind it too much as many of them are quite funny and unexpected though there is one choice where it forces you to choose the correct one around the middle of the game but it's not related to the plot. There are many clever references to other video games and even to the concept of visual novels throughout the story, though like most anime media there are a few adult references but thankfully they are not very inappropriate and are more funny then mature. The game is a fairly short to complete compare to an entire playthrough of Katawa Shoujo, about 2 and a half hours for me to finish Sepia Tears but what you get from playing this game is worth those hours. And it's all for free.

So whatever you're a fan of anime, romance or visual novels in general, Sepia Tears is a game that I recommend for those to play. Even though it has a linear story and fewer choices unlike other visual novels such as Katawa Shoujo which has multiple paths to play through and has a lot more emotions in its stories, it does something different compare to those games and I quite liked it.

There, I said it. Now can my heart stop feeling so happy and emotional right now.

First of all, this game is free, so the question is whether the time spent is worth it. To fully explore the content took me about 2.5 hours, and that was definitely worth it for me.

+ Attractive art - While the artwork is not the highest quality, it does its job well
+ Solid story - I found myself sympathizing with the characters and fairly invested in figuring out what was going on
+ Good writing (mostly) - The stream of consciousness was easy to follow and conversations flowed naturally (or didn't flow naturally as the story required!)
+ Pleasant music
+ Easy achievements (if you are into that)

- Redundancy - Some conversations are repetitive and I found myself starting to just skim a bit in some sections.
- Ending - While I personally enjoyed the ending, some might find the endings unsatisfactory for a VN. I don't really want to say more for spoiler purposes.

Overall I enjoyed my time with Sepia Tears. The more you enjoy VNs and anime the more you'll like this game.
